477aed3e-a2e2-4dea-be7c-b59a00e170cd Salting. Take half of salt and rub into back fat on all sides. Spread salt on the bottom of container. Place back fat skin down in a container. Spread salt on top. Place another slab of back fat on top of the first one using the same procedure. Keep container under refrigeration (40-42º F, 4-6º C).
477aed3e-a2e2-4dea-be7c-b59a00e170cd After 7 days repeat procedure using second half of salt. Reverse order of slab placement: the slab that was previously on top goes on bottom now and vice versa. You can rub in any spices that you like for instance pepper, paprika, or coriander. Leave in a container for 1-2 weeks longer. This means that the total time is between 2 and 3 weeks.
477aed3e-a2e2-4dea-be7c-b59a00e170cd Shake off excess salt from the surface of back fat and wash the slab in a lukewarm water. This removes any crystalized salt that has accumulated on the surface.
477aed3e-a2e2-4dea-be7c-b59a00e170cd Make a hanging loop and hang at cool temperature for 12 hours to dry.
477aed3e-a2e2-4dea-be7c-b59a00e170cd Smoke with a thin cold smoke for 2 days until back fat develops light brown or brown color.
477aed3e-a2e2-4dea-be7c-b59a00e170cd Keep in refrigerator.
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 Immerse loin in brine and place for 2 days in refrigerator OR pump meat with 10% pump and then place it in leftover brine for 1 day only.
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 Remove all bones and trim down the fat until you reach the lean meat.
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 Place loin into leftover brine and keep for 5 days in refrigerator.
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 Making Brine: To make 50° brine (10° Baumé) add 1.2 pounds of salt to 1 gallon of water (3.8 liters). Add 130 g (7-½ Tbsp) of Cure #1. Add 226 g (½ lb) sugar. This amount of brine will cure about 17 lbs (7.3 kg) of meat.
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 Remove from brine, wash and soak in cold water for 1 hour.
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 Stuff into synthetic casing or stockinette and hang in a preheated to 130º F (54º C) smokehouse to dry. This should take 3-4 hours with vents wide open.
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 When loin is dry apply smoke and smoke for 3 hours at 150º F (66º C).
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 Increase temperature (no smoke) to 170º F (77º C) and hold until meat reaches internal temperature of 154º F (68º C).
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 Shower for 5 minutes with cold water.
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 Hang at room temperature until loin is dry.
8dcdabe8-dec2-4480-9ae8-bd703ece52f5 Place in refrigerator.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Rub in 1/2 of the mixture on all sides.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc After 5 days overhaul and rub in another half. Keep under refrigeration. The meat will be cured im 10 to 15 days.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Soak bacon for one hour, brush the surface clean and hang until dry.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Smoke with a thin cold smoke for 1-2 days.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Refrigerate.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Bacon-Brine Cured, Brine: 60º SAL brine, 3.8 liters, 1 gallon
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Cure #1, 81 g, 13½ tsp.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Bacon is placed for 10 days in curing solution. The pieces are overhauled in the middle of the process.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Bacon is soaked for one hour in fresh water and the surface brushed off clean.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Bacon is hung to dry.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Bacon is smoked with cold smoke for 2 days.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Refrigerate.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Bacon - Injection Cured
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Bacon is needle injected with the above 60º SAL curing solution at 10% pump.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Bacon is left in for 5 days in the same strength solution. Bacon is rinsed and left to dry.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Bacon is smoked with cold smoke for 2 days.
281a3c27-94d1-49cb-813e-91988c04c6bc Refrigerate.
5a4a2ec6-b059-4403-995d-0a50f450e291 Remove all fat, connective tissue and silver skin.
5a4a2ec6-b059-4403-995d-0a50f450e291 Mix salt, Cure #2 and all ingredients together. Take ½ of the mixture and rub into the meat. Place in zip-loc® bag and put for 3 days into refrigerator.
5a4a2ec6-b059-4403-995d-0a50f450e291 Remove from the bag and apply the second half of the mixture. Drain away any liquid from the bag. Place in refrigerator for 3 more days.
5a4a2ec6-b059-4403-995d-0a50f450e291 Brush off excess mixture from the meat. Stuff into synthetic or collagen casings.
5a4a2ec6-b059-4403-995d-0a50f450e291 Hang for 4 weeks at 54º F (12º C) to dry and mature.
9fb25ead-fbb8-47a1-9f45-787ded0ee58b Make 1 liter/quart gelatin. Add 1 Tbs white vinegar and 1 Tbs white wine.
9fb25ead-fbb8-47a1-9f45-787ded0ee58b Pour a small amount of hot gelatin on the bottom of container, then place it in a refrigerator.
9fb25ead-fbb8-47a1-9f45-787ded0ee58b Once the solution hardens, place a slice of orange, hard boiled egg, carrot, apple or any decoration of your choice on top of solid gelatin.
9fb25ead-fbb8-47a1-9f45-787ded0ee58b More hot gelatin is added again to set the slices of fruit in place and the container is placed in the refrigerator again.
9fb25ead-fbb8-47a1-9f45-787ded0ee58b Once the solution solidifies it is removed from the refrigerator and the whole pieces of cold chicken breast are placed into the container. 6. The container is filled with gelatin and placed in the refrigerator overnight for the jelly to solidify.
9fb25ead-fbb8-47a1-9f45-787ded0ee58b Before serving the container is flipped upside down so that the entire product drops out. It helps to dip the container first for a short while in hot water to melt a tiny amount of gelatin that is attached to the container inside.
03fb856f-f536-4de3-b449-eed3352a2e25 Trim excess fat all around the butt. Keep the butt in refrigerator to keep it cold.
03fb856f-f536-4de3-b449-eed3352a2e25 Mix salt, Cure #2, sugar and all spices together. This is your spice mixture. Rub the meat on all sides with half of the spice mixture. Place the butt for 9 days in refrigerator. Keep it covered with plastic wrap or a cloth to prevent drying. You can place it in a zip lock bag too.
03fb856f-f536-4de3-b449-eed3352a2e25 After 9 days, rub the butt with the remaining spice mixture and keep in refrigerator for an additional 9 days.
03fb856f-f536-4de3-b449-eed3352a2e25 Remove from refrigerator, rinse the surface with tap water to remove any crystallized salt. Let it dry on the refrigerator’s screen for 3 hours.
03fb856f-f536-4de3-b449-eed3352a2e25 Make another flavoring spice mixture: 1 Tablespoon of brown sugar, 1 teaspoon of black pepper, 1 teaspoon of coarsely ground fennel. Rub into coppa.
03fb856f-f536-4de3-b449-eed3352a2e25 Stuff the butt into beef bungs or 100 mm collagen casings. Prick air pockets to allow entrapped air to escape. Do this especially at the two ends, and anywhere you see pockets of air.
03fb856f-f536-4de3-b449-eed3352a2e25 Hold butts for 21 days at around 55° F (14° C), 70% humidity to dry and mature. Do not go over 59° F (15° C).
45cf8d33-080d-4152-9df9-713dad82354f Pump spray ham with 6 - 7% of it's green weight ( 0.3 - 0.35 kg, 10 - 12 oz) of brine (salt, water and Cure # 1). About 7 - 9 syringe injections. After pumping immerse ham in the remaining brine and place in a refrigerator for 10 - 14 days.Turn over meat once every few days and keep an eye on the brine. The meat must be completely covered with brine, use weight if needed. Any symptoms of liquid going murky, accumulation of foam or slime on top or unpleasant smell, require brine change. Check the meat as well but that is very unlikely that it might be going bad. If brine's color becomes reddish don't worry it's normal. If you do it first time, check brine on a daily basis, you will sleep better at night.
45cf8d33-080d-4152-9df9-713dad82354f Once curing is done, check the meat and it's smell and color. Place hams for 3 hours under running water. You may place them in a large pot, but you will heve to change water once in a while.This time may be shorter if smaller pieces of meat are rinsed. After one hour get a tiny piece from inside and boil or fry it to see that the taste is what you are looking for. Then wash them briefly in warm water 86 - 104 F (30 - 40 C) and clean them on outside by scrubbing with a brush or knife. That removes any accumulation of salt crystals that may prevent proper smoke penetration.
45cf8d33-080d-4152-9df9-713dad82354f After rinsing hang hams or place them on wire screen over the sink or some other vessel. Let them drain for 12 - 24 hours.
45cf8d33-080d-4152-9df9-713dad82354f Now it's the time for the bone removal if your ham has one and getting rid of any gristle, sinew and elements that we feel are not needed. Roll up the ham and tie it with butcher twine - twice lenghtwise and every 2" (4 - 5 cm) across. Make on one end a hanging loop for smoking. Even up any irregular areas for uniform shape.
45cf8d33-080d-4152-9df9-713dad82354f Apply warm smoke, 86 - 104 F (30 - 40 C ) for 3 - 4 hours until light yellow to light brown color develops.
45cf8d33-080d-4152-9df9-713dad82354f Hams are placed in boiling water and boiled for 15 min. Water temperature is then lowered to 176 - 180 F (80 - 82 C) and hams are poached at this temperature until the inside temperature is 154 - 158F ( 68 - 70 C).The estimated time is about 50 min for 1 kg of weight. This time includes 15 min of boiling.
45cf8d33-080d-4152-9df9-713dad82354f Shower with cold water until the internal temperature is reduced to 110 F (44 C). Hang at room temperature for 1 hour then place in refrigerator.
760eb933-9ce5-4aaa-b157-257b34bc6225 Remove skin. Cut meat into 1” (25 mm) pieces. Grind skin with ⅛” (3 mm) plate. Save fat trimmings for other sausages.
760eb933-9ce5-4aaa-b157-257b34bc6225 Dilute salt, Cure #1 and sugar in 100 ml of water and pour over meat.
760eb933-9ce5-4aaa-b157-257b34bc6225 Stir meat pieces, kneading them lightly. Add spices and ground skin and mix everything together.
760eb933-9ce5-4aaa-b157-257b34bc6225 Stuff meat pieces into a cooking bag tightly, trying not to trap unnecessary air.
760eb933-9ce5-4aaa-b157-257b34bc6225 Place the bag inside the ham press. Apply slight pressure.
760eb933-9ce5-4aaa-b157-257b34bc6225 Place the ham press in a refrigerator for 48 hours. This is the curing step.
760eb933-9ce5-4aaa-b157-257b34bc6225 Apply pressure to the cover and place the ham mold in hot water. Cook for 60 minutes at 176º F (80º C). A five pound ham (2.5 kg) may need 3 hours cooking time.
760eb933-9ce5-4aaa-b157-257b34bc6225 Place the ham press for 2-3 hours in cold water to cool and then place overnight in a refrigerator.
760eb933-9ce5-4aaa-b157-257b34bc6225 Remove the ham from the mold. Keep refrigerated.
27c6ee4d-0996-45db-b32d-5cf9c938adfb Remove skin. Cut meat pieces into 1” (25 mm) cubes.
27c6ee4d-0996-45db-b32d-5cf9c938adfb Grind all meat through 3/16” (5 mm) plate.
27c6ee4d-0996-45db-b32d-5cf9c938adfb Mix meat with salt and Cure #1. Pack tightly in a container, cover with cloth and leave in a refrigerator for 2 days.
27c6ee4d-0996-45db-b32d-5cf9c938adfb Mix cured meat with all ingredients until mixture feels sticky.
27c6ee4d-0996-45db-b32d-5cf9c938adfb Stuff mixture into cellophane bag whose size corresponds to the size of your ham press. Place the bag into the ham press and apply pressure to the cover.
27c6ee4d-0996-45db-b32d-5cf9c938adfb Insert the ham press into boiling water but cook at 176º F (80º C) until meat reaches 154-160º F (68-71º C). In a small ham press, for example 4” diameter and 4-6” high, that will take about 2 hours.
27c6ee4d-0996-45db-b32d-5cf9c938adfb Place ham press for 2-3 hours in cold water to cool and then place overnight in refrigerator.
27c6ee4d-0996-45db-b32d-5cf9c938adfb Remove ham from the press.
7914700c-80c9-4bde-b552-11bd9348a9b7 Making Brine: Salt: 0.6kg (1.6 lb) Cure #1: 120 g (4.2 oz) Sugar: 42 g (1.5 oz) Cold water 3.8 l (1 gal)
7914700c-80c9-4bde-b552-11bd9348a9b7 Pump ham with 60º SAL brine (combine water, salt, Cure #1 and water together). Percent injection: 7%. The weight of cover pickle: 40% in relation to meat’s weight.
7914700c-80c9-4bde-b552-11bd9348a9b7 Immerse pumped ham in cover pickle for 10-14 days at refrigerator temperature. Overhaul (turn around) hams every few days.
7914700c-80c9-4bde-b552-11bd9348a9b7 Soak for 3 hours in cold running water. Rinse in lukewarm water (86 - 104º F, 30 - 40º C), using a brush to clean the surface.
7914700c-80c9-4bde-b552-11bd9348a9b7 Hang or place on a screen for 12 - 24 hours to dry.
7914700c-80c9-4bde-b552-11bd9348a9b7 Stuff in netting.
7914700c-80c9-4bde-b552-11bd9348a9b7 Smoke with warm smoke (86 - 104º F, 30 - 40º C), for 4 hours until skin develops light yellow - light brown color.
7914700c-80c9-4bde-b552-11bd9348a9b7 Insert ham into boiling water and keep boiling for 15 minutes. Lower water temperature to (176-180º F, 80-82º C) and continue cooking until the internal meat temperature becomes 154-158º F, 68-70º C. A rule of thumb calls for 50 minutes cooking for 1 kg of ham.
7914700c-80c9-4bde-b552-11bd9348a9b7 Place on shelves/screens to cool down.
7914700c-80c9-4bde-b552-11bd9348a9b7 Keep refrigerated.
910b4831-4dec-4057-9bee-6be1f382990b Mix salt, Cure #2 and sugar together. Divide into three equal parts. Rub ham on all sides with ⅓ of the mixture. Place ham in refrigerator. Keep it covered with plastic wrap or a cloth to prevent drying. A good idea is to keep it in a zip- loc bag. This prevents the ham from drying. The ham should be kept at around 90% humidity, but the humidity in a refrigerator is only about 40%.
910b4831-4dec-4057-9bee-6be1f382990b After 3 days, rub the ham with another ⅓ mixture and place in a refrigerator.
910b4831-4dec-4057-9bee-6be1f382990b After 10 days remove the ham from the refrigerator and apply the last ⅓ of the mixture. Place ham back in refrigerator.
910b4831-4dec-4057-9bee-6be1f382990b After 40 days (total salting time) remove the ham from the refrigerator and briefly rinse with tap water. Brush off any salt from the surface.
910b4831-4dec-4057-9bee-6be1f382990b Coat the surface of the ham with pepper and stuff the ham into the netting.
910b4831-4dec-4057-9bee-6be1f382990b Keep for 14 days at 40-42° F (4-6° C), 75% humidity.
910b4831-4dec-4057-9bee-6be1f382990b Apply cold smoke (77° F, 25° C) for 24 hours.
910b4831-4dec-4057-9bee-6be1f382990b Ripe (dry and mature) hams for 60 days at 77-86° F, 25-30° C), 65% humidity.
80f2555c-0b31-4a36-949e-c54306ad3d6e Remove skin. Cut meat pieces into 1” (25 mm) cubes.
80f2555c-0b31-4a36-949e-c54306ad3d6e Add salt and Cure #1 to meat and mix together. Pack tightly in a container, cover with cloth and leave for 3 days in refrigerator. Make brine adding 2½ tsp of salt to 60 ml (¼ cup) of water. This will make 40º SAL brine. No nitrite is needed for curing skins. Leave skins in brine for 3 days in refrigerator.
80f2555c-0b31-4a36-949e-c54306ad3d6e Poach skins in hot water (just below boiling) for 30 minutes. Drain skins, then cool them.
80f2555c-0b31-4a36-949e-c54306ad3d6e Grind skins through ⅛” (3 mm) plate.
80f2555c-0b31-4a36-949e-c54306ad3d6e Mix cured meat pieces with pepper. Knead meat hard until feels sticky. Add ground skins and mix everything well together.
80f2555c-0b31-4a36-949e-c54306ad3d6e Stuff mixture into cellophane bag whose size corresponds to the size of your ham press. Place the bag into the ham press and apply pressure to the cover.
80f2555c-0b31-4a36-949e-c54306ad3d6e Insert ham press into boiling water but cook at 176º F (80º C) until meat reaches 154-160º F (68-71º C). In a small ham press, for example 4” diameter and 4-6” high, that will take about 2 hours.
80f2555c-0b31-4a36-949e-c54306ad3d6e Place ham press for 2-3 hours in cold water to cool and then place overnight in refrigerator.
80f2555c-0b31-4a36-949e-c54306ad3d6e Remove ham from the press.
80f2555c-0b31-4a36-949e-c54306ad3d6e Keep in refrigerator.
39f64f2c-6d78-4e8e-a02c-f840e26c086d Pre-freeze meat so it will be easier to slice.
39f64f2c-6d78-4e8e-a02c-f840e26c086d Cut partially thawed meat into long slices about ¼" thick and an inch or two wide. For tender jerky, cut at right angles to long muscles (across the grain). Remove visible fat to help prevent off-flavors.
39f64f2c-6d78-4e8e-a02c-f840e26c086d Prepare marinade of your choice in a large sauce pan.
39f64f2c-6d78-4e8e-a02c-f840e26c086d Pour marinade over the meat and marinate jerky 12-24 hours. Overhaul jerky pieces at least once.
39f64f2c-6d78-4e8e-a02c-f840e26c086d Dry at 140-150° F (60-66º C) in dehydrator, oven or smoker. You can apply smoke for 30 minutes at this stage. Test for doneness by letting a piece cool. When cool, it should crack but not break when bent.
39f64f2c-6d78-4e8e-a02c-f840e26c086d Refrigerate and when cool check again for doneness. If necessary, dry further.
c3a19a84-f11f-4712-93d6-b5b277731575 Cut meat into strips about ¼” (6 mm) thick.
c3a19a84-f11f-4712-93d6-b5b277731575 Bring the marinade to a full boil over medium heat.
c3a19a84-f11f-4712-93d6-b5b277731575 Add a few meat strips, making sure there is enough marinade to cover them. Reheat to a full boil.
c3a19a84-f11f-4712-93d6-b5b277731575 Remove quickly meat strips and place on a drying screen.
c3a19a84-f11f-4712-93d6-b5b277731575 Repeat steps 3 & 4 until all meat strips have been precooked.
c3a19a84-f11f-4712-93d6-b5b277731575 Dry at 140º F (60º C) in dehydrator, oven or smoker. You can apply smoke for 30 minutes at this stage.
c3a19a84-f11f-4712-93d6-b5b277731575 Cool a sample piece of jerky and bend it. It should crack but not break.
c3a19a84-f11f-4712-93d6-b5b277731575 When done, place jerky in a plastic bag and refrigerate.
ccf561ad-c825-4ae4-93cb-9674df7f35c2 Soak livers in cold water for 30 minutes, then grind them through ⅛” (3 mm) grinder plate or chop them in a food processor until bubbles appear on the surface of the emulsion which may take 5-10 minutes.
ccf561ad-c825-4ae4-93cb-9674df7f35c2 Grind meats through ¼” (6 mm) plate.
ccf561ad-c825-4ae4-93cb-9674df7f35c2 Dissolve gelatin in water.
ccf561ad-c825-4ae4-93cb-9674df7f35c2 Mix everything together.
ccf561ad-c825-4ae4-93cb-9674df7f35c2 Stuff into a ham press.
ccf561ad-c825-4ae4-93cb-9674df7f35c2 Transfer mold press to a cooking tank with hot water.
ccf561ad-c825-4ae4-93cb-9674df7f35c2 Let the temperature drop to 160°F (72° C) and hold this temperature until internal meat temperature reaches 154° F (68° C).
ccf561ad-c825-4ae4-93cb-9674df7f35c2 Chill loaves in cold water and then transfer to refrigerator overnight.
ccf561ad-c825-4ae4-93cb-9674df7f35c2 Remove loaf from the mold press.
ccf561ad-c825-4ae4-93cb-9674df7f35c2 Keep refrigerated.
9d49590c-f677-444f-8fc0-c093bea27dd3 Remove all bones and trim down the fat until you reach the lean meat.
9d49590c-f677-444f-8fc0-c093bea27dd3 Mix salt, Cure #2 and all ingredients together.
9d49590c-f677-444f-8fc0-c093bea27dd3 Add little water to the mixture and rub the wet mixture into the loin.
9d49590c-f677-444f-8fc0-c093bea27dd3 Place into a plastic bag and leave for 7-10 days in refrigerator.
9d49590c-f677-444f-8fc0-c093bea27dd3 Remove loin from refrigerator and brush off the excess salt. Stuff into synthetic or collagen casings.
9d49590c-f677-444f-8fc0-c093bea27dd3 Hang loin at 46º F (8º C), 72-80% humidity for one month. This is the salt equalization stage.
9d49590c-f677-444f-8fc0-c093bea27dd3 Dry loins for 3 weeks at 68-72º F (20-22º C). Moisture removal and flavor development takes place at this stage.
9d49590c-f677-444f-8fc0-c093bea27dd3 Loin is ready when it loses about 40% of its original weight.
59458646-c98d-4da7-afe4-531e6f0b38ec Mix salt and Cure #1 together.
59458646-c98d-4da7-afe4-531e6f0b38ec Rub ½ of the mix into the belly.
59458646-c98d-4da7-afe4-531e6f0b38ec Place the belly in a zip lock plastic bag. Leave for 4 days in refrigerator.
59458646-c98d-4da7-afe4-531e6f0b38ec Remove the belly from the bag. Mix all spices with the remaining half of the curing mixture (salt and cure #1). Rub the mixture into the belly. Refrigerate for 4 more days.
59458646-c98d-4da7-afe4-531e6f0b38ec Wash belly with tap water and then soak it for 15 minutes in cold water.
59458646-c98d-4da7-afe4-531e6f0b38ec Dry belly for 2 days at 54° F (12° C).
59458646-c98d-4da7-afe4-531e6f0b38ec Remove the skin and divide the belly in two cutting along its length.
59458646-c98d-4da7-afe4-531e6f0b38ec Soak 5” (120 mm) fibrous casing for 1 hour in water. Roll each belly into a tight roll and insert into the casing. Run butcher twine around the pancetta every ¾” and make a hanging loop. Remove any air pockets with a needle.
59458646-c98d-4da7-afe4-531e6f0b38ec Hang for 3 weeks at 54° F (12° C).
59458646-c98d-4da7-afe4-531e6f0b38ec Refrigerate.
6ea2359e-6ccd-4914-b99a-32c9eca3ae88 Cut meat into 8 x 3 x 2" slices.
6ea2359e-6ccd-4914-b99a-32c9eca3ae88 Mix salt with Cure #2 and rub the mixture into the meat.
6ea2359e-6ccd-4914-b99a-32c9eca3ae88 Sprinkle some salt in a container and place meat slices on top of one another, separating them with salt. Place a wooden board on top of them and put a weight on top. Pastırma is a noun derived from the verb pastırmak (bastırmak in modern Turkish), which means "to press".
6ea2359e-6ccd-4914-b99a-32c9eca3ae88 Keep for 1 week in refrigerator.
6ea2359e-6ccd-4914-b99a-32c9eca3ae88 Remove meat from the refrigerator and wash with water. Brush off the surface of any salt. Place again in a container for 1 more day, covering meat with a weighted board. This will drain more liquid away.
6ea2359e-6ccd-4914-b99a-32c9eca3ae88 Mix all ingredients adding 1 tsp of salt. Add a little water and make the mixture into a paste (known as çemen).
6ea2359e-6ccd-4914-b99a-32c9eca3ae88 Cover the meat with the paste and hang in a dry, well ventilated area (50-59º F, 10-15º C, 60% humidity). You can use hooks or netting. After about 5 days the paste has dried and Pastirma is ready although it may be further dried.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Curing solution: 35 degrees SAL (10 Baume), 101 g salt per 1 liter of water Salt, 90 g (5 Tbsp) Cure #1, 18 g (1 Tbsp) Sugar, 10 g (2 tsp) Water, 1 liter
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Spice mixture: Black pepper, cracked, 10 g (1 Tbsp) Coriander seeds, whole or cracked, 10 g (1 Tbsp) Garlic, 3.5 g (1 clove)
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Mix brine ingredients in warm water, then cool the brine in refrigerator.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Pumping meat. Pump brisket with 10% curing solution (brisket should weigh 110% of its original weight). Add the remaining brine to cover the meat and cure for 2 days (3-4 days for 2-3 kg meat). OR
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a No pumping meat. Cover brisket with brine and cure for 4 days. Use about 4 days per 1 kg of meat.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Remove brisket from brine, wash, drain and wipe dry.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Coat the brisket with spice mixture. Be generous with your rub, it should be applied in a thick coating.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Hang in a preheated to 130° F (54° C) smokehouse (no smoke applied). With dampers fully open, hold at this temperature for about one hour, until meat surface is dry.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Re-adjust dampers to 1/4 open and apply light smoke for 2 hours. Raise temperature to 200 - 220° F (93 - 104° C). Cook until an internal temperature of 165°F (74° C) is reached.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Hang at room temperature for 1-2 hours. Serve or refrigerate.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Pastrami may be dry cured. For 1 kg (2.20 lb.) beef use: Salt, 35 g, 2 Tbsp. Cure #1, 5 g (1 tsp). This comes to 312 ppm of sodium nitrite. The USDA allows 625 ppm for dry curing meat. Sodium nitrite dissipates rapidly, after curing, smoking and cooking not much is left. Note: there is 4.69 g salt in Cure #1
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Spice mixture: Cracked black pepper, 3 tsp Coriander seeds, 3 tsp. Brown sugar, 2 tsp. Garlic, 1 clove, finely minced
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Mix salt, cure, and spice mixture together and rub it into the meat. Massage it well and cover the meats surface evenly.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Place meat in a Ziplock plastic bag.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Hold in a refrigerator for 5 days, turning the package daily.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Remove meat from the package, rinse with cold water, drain, pat dry with paper towel.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Make another spice mixture and coat the brisket with it. Be generous with your rub, it should be applied in a thick coating.
7bb17514-29a4-4a18-a30b-59fc0e77d46a Smoking/cooking - follow steps 8, 9, and 10.
bc3a1e79-0fa7-4be7-ba0d-32c6dd76b817 Chop jerky very finely with a knife or grind in a blender to a powder.
bc3a1e79-0fa7-4be7-ba0d-32c6dd76b817 Grind/chop other ingredients and mix with pulverized jerky.
bc3a1e79-0fa7-4be7-ba0d-32c6dd76b817 Mix jerky powder with powdered fruits.
bc3a1e79-0fa7-4be7-ba0d-32c6dd76b817 Cut the fat (suet, also known as tallow) into chunks and melt down over low heat, until it becomes a yellow-brown liquid. Continue to heat, stirring often, until more moisture is removed. Strain it through the filter to remove any impurities and allow to cool - it will become white.
bc3a1e79-0fa7-4be7-ba0d-32c6dd76b817 Reheat tallow over low heat and pour over jerky-fruit mixture. The tallow should be cool enough to touch but still liquid.
bc3a1e79-0fa7-4be7-ba0d-32c6dd76b817 Place warm pemmican into suitable molds to make blocks or bars. If pemmican solidifies too fast, you can warm it up again in a microwave.
bc3a1e79-0fa7-4be7-ba0d-32c6dd76b817 Wrap it up in wax paper or store in plastic bags.
fdf7c1b6-8775-4d0a-9a8b-da720a820d5c Cover the meat and bones with cold water, add salt, pepper and onions and bring to a boil. Reduce heat, skim off the foam cover with lid and simmer for 1-2 hours until meat is tender.
fdf7c1b6-8775-4d0a-9a8b-da720a820d5c Remove the meat, scrape off the meat from the bones. Discard bones but save the stock.
fdf7c1b6-8775-4d0a-9a8b-da720a820d5c Chop the meat very fine by hand or grind through 3/16” (4 mm) plate.
fdf7c1b6-8775-4d0a-9a8b-da720a820d5c Place meat in stock, mix and taste. Add more salt or pepper if needed. Many recipes call for additional spices, now is the time to add them.
fdf7c1b6-8775-4d0a-9a8b-da720a820d5c Make sure the stock with meat is hot and start slowly adding buckwheat flour stirring the mixture with a paddle. Make sure it is smooth and thick - the paddle should stand up in the pot
fdf7c1b6-8775-4d0a-9a8b-da720a820d5c Pack the mixture into baking pans about 8 x 4 x 2” or 9 x 4 x 3”. The pans should be either oiled or lined up with wax paper. Cover and place in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours.
fdf7c1b6-8775-4d0a-9a8b-da720a820d5c Cut into 1/2” individual slices. To freeze, place the slices between pieces of butcher paper.
8e16bd8d-d176-4329-8fa7-6e99c6c16de0 Pigs feet are immersed for 12 days in 1 gallon 80º SAL brine
8e16bd8d-d176-4329-8fa7-6e99c6c16de0 Pigs feet are removed from brine, skinned and the entire foot is cooked for 3-4 hours at 200º F, 94º C (below boiling point) until meat separates from bones.
8e16bd8d-d176-4329-8fa7-6e99c6c16de0 Feet are rinsed in cold water, then placed in a refrigerator.
8e16bd8d-d176-4329-8fa7-6e99c6c16de0 Feet are split and semi-boned.
8e16bd8d-d176-4329-8fa7-6e99c6c16de0 They are placed in jars with white vinegar. Whole peppercorns and bay leaves are added for flavoring.
f21870fc-e8db-4b54-99eb-dcf6ceb4bc58 Mix all ingredients in 1 qt of cold water (40° F, 4° C), then spray pump pork butts to 10% of the green (original) weight.
f21870fc-e8db-4b54-99eb-dcf6ceb4bc58 Leave butts in the remaining brine for 3 - 4 days in a refrigerator.
f21870fc-e8db-4b54-99eb-dcf6ceb4bc58 Take them out, wash briefly with cold water and let drain.
f21870fc-e8db-4b54-99eb-dcf6ceb4bc58 Place butts in stockinette bag or hang them on hooks.
f21870fc-e8db-4b54-99eb-dcf6ceb4bc58 Hang them in a preheated to 130° F (54° C) smokehouse for 2-3 hours until dry.
f21870fc-e8db-4b54-99eb-dcf6ceb4bc58 Apply a medium smoke increasing temperature to 150° F for about 3 hours.
f21870fc-e8db-4b54-99eb-dcf6ceb4bc58 Raise the temperature to 160–165° F and continue smoking until an internal temperature of 154° F (68° C) is obtained.
f21870fc-e8db-4b54-99eb-dcf6ceb4bc58 Shower with cold water and hang them at room temperature to start cooling.
f21870fc-e8db-4b54-99eb-dcf6ceb4bc58 Store in the refrigerator.
d15ca0fd-ce58-474e-a039-35ff72d89578 Keep lean meats separate from fat trimmings. Grind lean meats through 3/16” plate (5 mm). Refreeze and grind again. Refreeze again and grind through 1/8” (3 mm) plate. Grind fat trimmings through 1/8” (3 mm) plate, refreeze and grind again.
d15ca0fd-ce58-474e-a039-35ff72d89578 Mix lean ground pork with all ingredients adding 50 ml of cold water. Add ground fat pork and 50 ml of cold water and mix well. Add fat trimmings and the last 50 ml of water and mix everything well together.
d15ca0fd-ce58-474e-a039-35ff72d89578 Stuff firmly into 28-32 mm hog casings. Form 4-5” (10-12 cm) long links.
d15ca0fd-ce58-474e-a039-35ff72d89578 Cook in hot water, at 167º F, 75º C until internal meat temperature reaches 154-158º F (68-70º C). This should take about 15 minutes.
d15ca0fd-ce58-474e-a039-35ff72d89578 Shower with cold water for 5 minutes.
d15ca0fd-ce58-474e-a039-35ff72d89578 Keep in a refrigerator.
6fd5cd02-0a93-420b-ba09-dc50faf6bf91 Grind pork through ⅜” (10 mm) plate.
6fd5cd02-0a93-420b-ba09-dc50faf6bf91 Mix ground meat with all ingredients.
6fd5cd02-0a93-420b-ba09-dc50faf6bf91 Stuff into pans and bake at 212° F (100° C) until the internal temperature reaches 154° F (68° C).
6fd5cd02-0a93-420b-ba09-dc50faf6bf91 Let cool in refrigerator before removing from the pan and slicing.
bfa82454-b3a0-4a35-b2d4-33cd46d562ce Wet cure method. Mix all ingredients with cold water. Using a needle syringe, pump the loin to 3-4 % of its green weight. That means you are taking the amount of brine that equals 3-4% of the loin meat weight. In this case it comes to 60-80 g (2.1 - 2.8 oz) or 1/3 cup. The loin then is placed in the leftover brine and placed in a refrigerator for 1 day. If meat is not pump injected, leave it in brine for 2 days, overhauling on the second day. Loins must be covered with brine, use some kind of weight on top of them.
bfa82454-b3a0-4a35-b2d4-33cd46d562ce Wash the outside of the loin briefly with tap water. It is wise to taste it now and if it is too salty place in cold water (refrigerator) for a few hours. If you want it saltier, stick it back into the brine for a few hours. Let it drain and dry for 6-8 hours at room temperature. Then you can rub the dry loin all over with the yolk of an egg. That will give the loin a beautiful gold color on the outside after smoking.
bfa82454-b3a0-4a35-b2d4-33cd46d562ce Preheat the smoker to 130º F(54º C) and if the loin is dry, introduce smoke with dampers 1/4 closed and smoke for 1 hour at 122-140° F (50-60° C). Increase smoking temperature to 150° F (66° C) applying smoke all the time and stop when the meat’s internal temperature reaches 142º F (61º C). Trichinae, almost non-existent in American pork, dies at 137º F(58º C).
bfa82454-b3a0-4a35-b2d4-33cd46d562ce Shower with cold water until the internal temperature is reduced to 110° F (44° C). Hang at room temperature for 1 hour then place in a refrigerator.
b01144b4-ae46-40a2-a99d-f3fab309b9fb Place pigs feet in cold water, add whole peppercorns, bay leaf, carrot, onion and cook pigs feet until meat separates from bones. Use enough water to cover the feet. This might take 3 hours.
b01144b4-ae46-40a2-a99d-f3fab309b9fb Remove feet but save the stock. Remove fat from the top, then clarify meat stock by filtering it through cheese cloth. Add about 1.5% of vinegar which comes to about 1 Tsp per liter of stock.
b01144b4-ae46-40a2-a99d-f3fab309b9fb Separate meat from bones when feet are still hot.
b01144b4-ae46-40a2-a99d-f3fab309b9fb Pour a little stock into the container.
b01144b4-ae46-40a2-a99d-f3fab309b9fb Place meat on the bottom of the container.
b01144b4-ae46-40a2-a99d-f3fab309b9fb Pour stock carefully into the container.
b01144b4-ae46-40a2-a99d-f3fab309b9fb Place in refrigerator.
07f8e622-5ea9-42ec-b4fc-10cbd3943cfd Cut pork butt across the grain into 1” thick strips and remove excess fat. Mix together all ingredients and coat the pork strips on all sides. Place in a container (plastic Zip-Loc® bag is fine) and keep in refrigerator for 2 days. Turn pork strips over once a day or shake the bag.
07f8e622-5ea9-42ec-b4fc-10cbd3943cfd Remove the pork pieces and hang them on S-hooks for 1-2 hours until dry.
07f8e622-5ea9-42ec-b4fc-10cbd3943cfd Preheat smoker to 130º F, (55º C) and if meat feels dry apply smoke for 3 hours. If the surface of the tasso is still wet, hold it inside the smoker (no smoke) until it feels dry. Then in the last hour of smoking try to gradually increase the temperature to about 160º F, (71º C).
07f8e622-5ea9-42ec-b4fc-10cbd3943cfd Increase temperature to 170º-180º F, 77º-82º C, (no smoke necessary) and cook tasso to an internal temperature of 154º F (68º C).
07f8e622-5ea9-42ec-b4fc-10cbd3943cfd Store in refrigerator.
bafe3b60-6523-4bc3-9f01-96e17d346d84 Curing solution, 25 deg SAL, (6 Be): Salt, 30 g (5 tsp), Cure #1, 4.5 g (3/4 tsp), Sugar, 5 g (1 tsp), Water, 500 ml
bafe3b60-6523-4bc3-9f01-96e17d346d84 Remove any membrane and outside fat. Place 1 kg tenderloin in 0.5 l curing solution and cure for 3 days in refrigerator.
bafe3b60-6523-4bc3-9f01-96e17d346d84 Drain for 6 hours.
bafe3b60-6523-4bc3-9f01-96e17d346d84 Make a hanging loop 3 cm (1") at the thicker end.
bafe3b60-6523-4bc3-9f01-96e17d346d84 Crush garlic and add with paprika to 1 liter od water. Bring to a boil, then dip tenderloins for 30 seconds in the solution.
bafe3b60-6523-4bc3-9f01-96e17d346d84 Hang for 1 hour to dry.
bafe3b60-6523-4bc3-9f01-96e17d346d84 Apply hot smoke 45-60 C, 113-140 F, for 80-90 min, then bake for 20 minutes at 80-85 C, 176-185 F. The tenderloin should reach 60-70 C, 140-158 F internal meat temperature and be of the light brown color.
bafe3b60-6523-4bc3-9f01-96e17d346d84 Cool in the air to < 18 C, 64 F.
